original_title: Sri Lanka’s re-based Colombo inflation index falls to 50.6-pct in Feb 2023
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s inflation in the capital Colombo fell to  newly rebased Colombo Consumer Price Index 50.6 percent in February 2023, from 51.7 percent January, data from the state statistics office showed.
In the month of February 2023, the CCPI index climbed 0.9 percent with non-foods rising.
The food sub-index fell 2.2 percent, while non-foods, went up 1.8 percent.
Clothing and footwear went up 4.3 percent and housing, water, electricity and gas went up 3.5 percent.

The new CCPI index with a 2021 base shows slightly lower level of inflation than the earlier one. In periods of high inflation consumers shift to cheaper foods, a phenomenon known as shifting from hotdogs to dogfood.
Sri Lanka inflation started to rise steeply from around September 2021.
The central bank tightened monetary policy from around April 2022 after a float failed due to a surrender requirement.
The exchange rate was re-pegged at 360/370 to the US dollar with complementary monetary policy as the central bank gradually ended money printing.
The surrender requirement was relaxed this week and the rupee has strengthened, which will tend to bring down traded commodities further. (Colombo/Feb28/2023)
